ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Clinic
Have you been working at this facility for at least 3 months?
What is your job title?
Notes: 1=Facility manager; 2=Registered nurse or nursing sister; 3=Enrolled nurse; 4=Enrolled nursing auxiliary; other=77

ElementDescription: When did you first start working as a nurse?
When did you start working at this clinic?
About how many hours a week do/did you usually work?
How many hours of non-mandatory overtime do you work in one average week?
Approximately how many hours are you scheduled to work in one shift?
What time of day are your shifts usually scheduled?
What time of day are your shifts usually scheduled? Other
Have you received training in screening patients for depression?
Notes: 1=None; 2=In-service training; 3=Preservice training; 4=Both in-service and preservice training

ElementDescription: You can screen patients for depression.
Have you received training in assessing (diagnosing, examining, and investigating) patients for depression?
Notes: 1=None; 2=In-service training; 3=Preservice training; 4=Both in-service and preservice training

ElementDescription: You can assess (diagnose, examine, and investigate) patients with depression.
Have you received training in treating patients for depression?
Notes: 1=None; 2=In-service training; 3=Preservice training; 4=Both in-service and preservice training

ElementDescription: You can manage an emergency/crisis related to suicide attempt or ideation.
You can monitor and continue prescription of medication for depression.
You can provide appropriate follow up for patients with depression.
You can provide advice about their condition to people with depression.
Have you received training in referring patients to other care for depression?
Notes: 1=None; 2=In-service training; 3=Preservice training; 4=Both in-service and preservice training

ElementDescription: You can decide when to refer a person to a specialist/counsellor if they have depression.
How many of your chronic care patients do you screen for depression?
Notes: 1=None; 2=A few eligible patients; 3=About half of eligible patients; 4=Most eligible patients; 5=All eligible patients

ElementDescription: Among your patients who may have depression, how many do you assess (diagnose, examine, and investigate) for depression?
Notes: 1=None; 2=A few eligible patients; 3=About half of eligible patients; 4=Most eligible patients; 5=All eligible patients; 77=I have no patients who may have depression

ElementDescription: Among your patients with depression, how many do you monitor and continue prescription of medication for their depression?
Notes: 1=None; 2=A few eligible patients; 3=About half of eligible patients; 4=Most eligible patients; 5=All eligible patients; 77=I have no patients with depression

ElementDescription: Among your patients with depression, for how many do you provide appropriate follow up?
Notes: 1=None; 2=A few eligible patients; 3=About half of eligible patients; 4=Most eligible patients; 5=All eligible patients; 77=I have no patients with depression

ElementDescription: Among your patients with depression, for how many do you provide advice about their condition?
Notes: 1=None; 2=A few eligible patients; 3=About half of eligible patients; 4=Most eligible patients; 5=All eligible patients; 77=I have no patients with depression

ElementDescription: Among your patients with depression, for how many do you provide referral to a specialist/counsellor?
Notes: 1=None; 2=A few eligible patients; 3=About half of eligible patients; 4=Most eligible patients; 5=All eligible patients; 77=I have no patients with depression

ElementDescription: What are the three most important barriers to providing appropriate care for patients with depression in your facility?
Notes: 1=I do not have enough training; 2=I do not have enough practice; 3=I do not have enough supervision; 4=I do not have enough time; 5=I do not see patients with depression; 6=I do not have a screening tool; 7=I cannot prescribe appropriate medication; 8=I do not know where to refer patients; 9=I do not think treatment will help; 10=There is no counsellor; 11=I am not comfortable working with patients with depression; 77=Other

ElementDescription: What are the three most important barriers to providing appropriate care for patients with depression in your facility? Other
